Noam Chomsky Quotes


Noam Chomsky is a linguist and philosopher born in the United States in 1928. He laid the foundation for modern linguistics by exploring the universal structures and principles of language.

He is also known as a political activist, delivering critical views on power and the media.

He was also known for his political activism and his critical views on power and the media.

This quote was delivered in his book American Power and the New Mandarins, published in 1970.

In this book, he discusses his anti-war position on the Vietnam War and U.S. foreign policy, as well as the role of intellectuals and the media.


The meaning of this quote is that freedom is not simply following one's own desires, but choosing and acting on what one thinks is right.

Doing what one does not want is often difficult and painful, but it is still necessary to preserve one's freedom.



This quote is for those who find it difficult to live according to their own will and values. It means that those who are able to stand up for their beliefs without succumbing to the pressures and temptations of society, authority, and the media are truly free people.
